customer_name: Kay Rosaire and Clayton Rosaire Mowrey

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility failed to maintain a program of daily observations. Several of the goats in the petting zoo had moderate to
severely overgrown hoofs and dewclaws. The rear hooves, of one brown goat, were overgrown by approximately 2.5
inches. The inside claws were flattened and curled upward while the outside claws remained thin and curled out and
upward. The facility did not observe or identify these conditions.
Failure to properly observe and communicate animal health issues can lead to unnecessary discomfort, disease, and
injury.
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain a program of adequate veterinary care that includes daily observation of all
animals to assess their health and well-being. To be corrected by July 16, 2024.

The facility failed to maintain housing facilities in good repair.
• The wooden platform at the front of the coatimundi enclosure is in disrepair. The wood is separating and in a state of
decay.
• A metal vertical support beam and several metal cross braces are rusted through and no longer connected to the base
of the serval enclosure.
• The wooden platform, in the enclosure housing a mountain lion, is splintered and shredded, with rough, sharp edges.
• At least five the wooden dens and associated platforms in tiger enclosures throughout the facility are in a state of
disrepair. The wood is showing signs of decay, holes are chewed or torn in the walls and roofs of the dens and the
platforms are shredded and splintered with rough, sharp edges.
Failure to maintain housing facilities in good repair can affect the structural integrity of the enclosures which may lead to
the injury or escape of the animals contained in them. Broken and torn enclosure may also have rough or sharp edges
which can also lead to injury of the animal.
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals. To be corrected by August 9, 2024.

Two circular fans, in the wooden building used as the sheltered portion of tiger enclosures, were not clean. The wire
cages surrounding both fans were covered with dust, hair and debris.
Regular cleaning/housekeeping is necessary to prevent odors, eliminate breeding and living areas for pests and to reduce
the potential for spread of disease.
Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed
husbandry practices. To be corrected by July 23, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Mary Ann Archer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Bryan Voetberg, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility failed to maintain a program of daily observations. Several of the goats in the petting zoo had moderate to 
severely overgrown hoofs and dewclaws. The rear hooves, of one brown goat, were overgrown by approximately 2.5 
inches. The inside claws were flattened and curled upward while the outside claws remained thin and curled out and 
upward. The facility did not observe or identify these conditions. 
 
Failure to properly observe and communicate animal health issues can lead to unnecessary discomfort, disease, and 
injury. 
 
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain a program of adequate veterinary care that includes daily observation of all 
animals to assess their health and well-being. To be corrected by July 16, 2024. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The facility failed to maintain housing facilities in good repair.  
• The wooden platform at the front of the coatimundi enclosure is in disrepair. The wood is separating and in a state of 
decay. 
• A metal vertical support beam and several metal cross braces are rusted through and no longer connected to the base 
of the serval enclosure. 
• The wooden platform, in the enclosure housing a mountain lion, is splintered and shredded, with rough, sharp edges. 
• At least five the wooden dens and associated platforms in tiger enclosures throughout the facility are in a state of 
disrepair. The wood is showing signs of decay, holes are chewed or torn in the walls and roofs of the dens and the 
platforms are shredded and splintered with rough, sharp edges. 
 
Failure to maintain housing facilities in good repair can affect the structural integrity of the enclosures which may lead to 
the injury or escape of the animals contained in them. Broken and torn enclosure may also have rough or sharp edges 
which can also lead to injury of the animal.

Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals. To be corrected by August 9, 2024. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
Two circular fans, in the wooden building used as the sheltered portion of tiger enclosures, were not clean. The wire 
cages surrounding both fans were covered with dust, hair and debris. 
 
Regular cleaning/housekeeping is necessary to prevent odors, eliminate breeding and living areas for pests and to reduce 
the potential for spread of disease. 
 
Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed 
husbandry practices. To be corrected by July 23, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Mary Ann Archer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Bryan Voetberg, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
